body_html: I have run the amended script as per your directions (thanks), and I still get errors, many errors, but they seem to be around onx and misparsing \i in the cmake leading to the modules not being built and the link ultimately failing. But one in particular near the end in console.txt is very interesting – there is a complaint on the error message stream warning: no library file corresponding to 'C:/Program Files/NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit/CUDA/v9.0\lib/x64\cudnn.lib' found (skipping) however it is there: C:\temp\build_torch>dir "C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v9.0\lib\x64\cudnn.lib" Volume in drive C has no label. Volume Serial Number is 0C92-5FF4 Directory of C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v9.0\lib\x64 17/11/2017 04:51 41,814 cudnn.lib 1 File(s) 41,814 bytes 0 Dir(s) 114,585,493,504 bytes free Other errors also suggest there is a mis-parsing of slashes that are sometimes one way round and sometimes the other. (This error can be seen in the longer output as well). I am afraid I do not have time to analyse the errors right now but enclose the full build logs as they may well be helpful. The output of collect_env.py is: Collecting environment information... PyTorch version: 0.4.1 Is debug build: No CUDA used to build PyTorch: 9.0 OS: Microsoft Windows 10 Pro GCC version: (x86_64-posix-sjlj, built by strawberryperl.com project) 4.8.3 CMake version: Could not collect Python version: 3.6 Is CUDA available: Yes CUDA runtime version: 9.0.176 GPU models and configuration: GPU 0: Quadro K2100M Nvidia driver version: 385.54 cuDNN version: Probably one of the following: C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v9.0\bin\cudnn64_7.dll Versions of relevant libraries: [pip] Could not collect [conda] Could not collect From: David Brownell <notifications@github.com> Sent: 26 September 2018 18:13 To: pytorch/pytorch <pytorch@noreply.github.com> Cc: terrylyons <tlyons@maths.ox.ac.uk>; Mention <mention@noreply.github.com> Subject: Re: [pytorch/pytorch] Building from source on windows 10 - 67000 warnings and 12 link errors - 6 mpi and 6 other (#12001) @peterjc123<https://github.com/peterjc123> Another data point: I set the flags as described, rebuilt, and am running into the same linker errors. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<#12001 (comment)>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AGFm-wxyrAyZn5c4Zzp1gzY9-TIIRkkDks5ue7WpgaJpZM4W16iU>.
body_text:
I have run the amended script as per your directions (thanks), and I still get errors, many errors, but they seem to be around onx and misparsing \i in the cmake leading to the modules not being built and the link ultimately failing.  But one in particular near the end in console.txt is very interesting – there is a complaint on the error message stream
warning: no library file corresponding to 'C:/Program Files/NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit/CUDA/v9.0\lib/x64\cudnn.lib' found (skipping)
however it is there:

C:\temp\build_torch>dir "C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v9.0\lib\x64\cudnn.lib"
Volume in drive C has no label.
Volume Serial Number is 0C92-5FF4

Directory of C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v9.0\lib\x64

17/11/2017  04:51            41,814 cudnn.lib
               1 File(s)         41,814 bytes
               0 Dir(s)  114,585,493,504 bytes free

Other errors also suggest there is a mis-parsing of slashes that are sometimes one way round and sometimes the other. (This error can be seen in the longer output as well). I am afraid I do not have time to analyse the errors right now but enclose the full build logs as they may well be helpful.

The output of collect_env.py is:

Collecting environment information...
PyTorch version: 0.4.1
Is debug build: No
CUDA used to build PyTorch: 9.0

OS: Microsoft Windows 10 Pro
GCC version: (x86_64-posix-sjlj, built by strawberryperl.com project) 4.8.3
CMake version: Could not collect

Python version: 3.6
Is CUDA available: Yes
CUDA runtime version: 9.0.176
GPU models and configuration: GPU 0: Quadro K2100M
Nvidia driver version: 385.54
cuDNN version: Probably one of the following:
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v9.0\bin\cudnn64_7.dll

Versions of relevant libraries:
[pip] Could not collect
[conda] Could not collect



From: David Brownell <notifications@github.com>
Sent: 26 September 2018 18:13
To: pytorch/pytorch <pytorch@noreply.github.com>
Cc: terrylyons <tlyons@maths.ox.ac.uk>; Mention <mention@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [pytorch/pytorch] Building from source on windows 10 - 67000 warnings and 12 link errors - 6 mpi and 6 other (#12001)


@peterjc123<https://github.com/peterjc123> Another data point: I set the flags as described, rebuilt, and am running into the same linker errors.

—
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<#12001 (comment)>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AGFm-wxyrAyZn5c4Zzp1gzY9-TIIRkkDks5ue7WpgaJpZM4W16iU>.
body:
I have run the amended script as per your directions (thanks), and I still get errors, many errors, but they seem to be around onx and misparsing \i in the cmake leading to the modules not being built and the link ultimately failing.  But one in particular near the end in console.txt is very interesting – there is a complaint on the error message stream
warning: no library file corresponding to 'C:/Program Files/NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit/CUDA/v9.0\lib/x64\cudnn.lib' found (skipping)
however it is there:

C:\temp\build_torch>dir "C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v9.0\lib\x64\cudnn.lib"
Volume in drive C has no label.
Volume Serial Number is 0C92-5FF4

Directory of C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v9.0\lib\x64

17/11/2017  04:51            41,814 cudnn.lib
               1 File(s)         41,814 bytes
               0 Dir(s)  114,585,493,504 bytes free

Other errors also suggest there is a mis-parsing of slashes that are sometimes one way round and sometimes the other. (This error can be seen in the longer output as well). I am afraid I do not have time to analyse the errors right now but enclose the full build logs as they may well be helpful.

The output of collect_env.py is:
